b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (22:58): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: why is the impl. I referenced return new String(this); instead of return this, then?

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:01): it seems to not do anything

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (23:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: String in Java scope is java.lang.String and String inside /*-{ ... }-*/ is JavaScript String as far as I can tell
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:03): Hmm, too much magic for me to understand :-p
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (23:03): (I was wondering what type 'this' was, but then I decided it's probably safer to not know)

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (23:04): Dean Edwards about GWT / JSNI: "This is basically an admission that in the browser environment, JavaScript is king. If you ultimately need to fall back to JavaScript to fix your abstraction layer then your abstraction layer is leaking. JavaScript is king in the browser and GWT is for cowards."
